(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)
The USA Today's top reporter (who's written front page stories on the BOP) is asking if BOP is "designating specific officers to regularly monitor surveillance video in segregated housing units and other locations where inmates are at some risk for suicide."

(b)(5) (b)(6); (b)(7)(C) (b)(6); (b)(7)(C) (b)(6); (b)(7)(C)

(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)
(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)
Public Information Office
Federal Bureau of Prisons
(202) 353-(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)

>> (b)(6); (b)(7)(C) @usatoday.com> 10/22/2019 10:32 AM >>
Good morning,
In wake of the Epstein death, I understand that institutions across the bureau are designating specific officers to regularly monitor surveillance video in segregated housing units and other locations where inmates are at some risk for suicide.
Is there someone who may be able to elaborate on this effort?
Many thanks,
(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)
(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)
USA TODAY
703-854-(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)

text_blocks.content: plan), motivation, and subjective feelings of defeat or humiliation.

Public Information Office

(202) 353-(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)

The USA Today's top reporter (who's written front page stories on the BOP) is asking if BOP is "designating specific officers to regularly monitor surveillance video in segregated housing units and other locations where inmates are at some risk for suicide."

Public Information Office
Federal Bureau of Prisons
(202) 353-(b)(6); (b)(7)(C)

In wake of the Epstein death, I understand that institutions across the bureau are designating specific officers to regularly monitor surveillance video in segregated housing units and other locations where inmates are at some risk for suicide.
Is there someone who may be able to elaborate on this effort?

additional_notes: The document contains multiple redactions, primarily of personal contact information and names. The content appears to be email correspondence between the Federal Bureau of Prisons and USA Today regarding the monitoring of surveillance video in segregated housing units following the death of Epstein.
